title: Mining Demand And Supply Data With Methods Of Economic Statistics

author: Melita Hajdinjak, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, University of Ljubljana

segmentation: In economics, the amount of goods that consumers are willing to buy at a given price holding constant all the other factors that influence purchase is called quantity demanded.
The relationship between the unit price and the quantity demanded is shown by the demand curve, which is usually downward sloping because of the law of demand.
With some theoretical exceptions.
This is because the lower demand says that consumers consumers will buy more of a good or a service if the price falls.

And on the other hand, the amount of a good that firms want to sell at the given price is called quantity supplied, and the relationship between the unit price and quantity supplied is showed by the supply curve which is colored red.
It is usually upward sloping because of the law of supply, with some important exceptions, however.
These two curves, the demand and the supply curve meet at a price where the quantity demanded.
Or the quantity?
Which they produce.
The users are willing and able to to buy, and the quantity which the producers are willing and able to supply.
An equal, the intersection point is called the equilibrium.
A measure to show the responsiveness of the quantity demanded or supplied of a good or service to a change in its price is called price elasticity.
It is defined as the percentage change in quantity in response to 1% change in its price.
Um?
And if Q is the quantity demanded, price elasticity is usually negative or is negative for exactly those good goods that conform to the law of demand.
And if Q is the quantity supplies supplied, price elasticity is positive for exactly those goods that conform to the law of supply.
Notice that slope and electricity are different concepts.
So in.
For analytical convenience in theoretical demand and supply analysis, a special kind of price elasticity functions is used, namely, functions with constant price elasticity.
Which assumes that consumers and providers are equally sensitive to price changes.
Whatever the price might be, maybe.
Several studies, however, indicate that this is not always true by showing that price elasticity can be non constant in particular.
Um?
The elastic City of demand usually decreases with price and the elasticities of supply usually increases with price.
We should just also consider.
Functions were price, elasticity is directly proportional to price and functions where price elasticity is linearly dependent on the price.
So in the case of constant price elasticity, the curves are shown here.
The price and quantity.
Can be.
Um?
Are reversible or the quantity is reversible, so we can.
We can associate price with quantity uniquely, which is good and theoretically convenient.
And when the price is or the price elasticity is directly proportional to price.
This does not change.
There are no irreversible effects.
So again, price and quantity can be uniquely associated.
But in the most general case of linear price elasticity functions.
There are, there is more freedom.
There are more possibilities.
For instance, if both A&B.
Are positive or if both are negative, then there are no irreversible effects.
But in all the other cases, we get such irreversible functions.
And also Moreover, apart of these curves.
R. Are characteristic for dim and these are colored blue and the other parts are characteristic for supply.
They accord red.
So what do we want to do with these functions?
We want to detect.
Interesting patterns on dependencies in the data in demand and supply data, so we have prices we have demanded or supplied quantities.
And we have taken a data set, namely the monkey US oil imports data.
Where we had the information about thousands of barrels purchased and the information abroad about the unit price of barrels.
For all months between the years 1973 in 2007.
First, some basic facts.
The facts about this data.
Under petroleum we mean crude oil and petroleum products.
We could see on the on the previous picture that oil imports peaked in 2005 when they supplied 60% of the consumption.
After that.
There was a declination due to increased domestic oil production, introduced consumption in the United States.
And their largest source.
Largest sources of imported oil were Canada, Saudi Arabia, Mexico, Venezuela and Russia.
And also on the previous picture, the most visible peak of imported oil quantity was during the creation of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which started in 1975, right after the oil embargo.
So having in mind or goal to extract interesting patterns to automatic automatically extract interesting patterns and dependencies.
We first did perform some regression analysis.
Least squares regression, where we took these three kinds of functions, namely functions with constant price elasticity functions with.
Directly proportional price, elasticity and functions with linear price elasticity.
And this table shows the results or the obtained elasticities only for those years and only for those models.
Which have a satisfactory goodness of fit.
Also, an example graph is shown where all the three curves.
So with the three types of elasticities.
Are visualized, the green curve is of course the best.
The most general linear price elasticity curve which had in this case for the year 1980, coefficient of determination of zero point .5.
What are the results of this first regression analysis?
The goodness of fit and the statistical significance of the estimated parameters were high enough only for 11 of the 35 years which were observed.
The means of the models coefficients of determination for the three types of functions where 0.56 zero point, 5 seven, and for the most general, the best model 0.63.
More importantly.
Local peaks, which could be seen on the time sequence graph at the beginning.
A local peaks of purchase quantity resulted in linear price elasticity models, which are are typical atypical for dim and which are more typical for supply.
Although we are talking about dimaond of oil of petroleum.
And also a sequence of highly insignificant models.
Was observed these were between nineteen, 7075 and 1985, exactly in the period where the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was created.
And in the second step for two words or goal of finding some interesting patterns, some interesting.
Changes.
We have defined monthly price elasticities and monthly price elasticity slopes as this where you can see that the monthly price elasticities.
Are basically defined.
Just like this, we took the price elasticity definition and replaced the differential with differentials with the differences.
And in the mountain, the definition of the monthly electricity slopes, we just assumed linear price elasticity of demand.
So we got this.
These definitions were created or introduced with the aim to detect automatically detect some stable or some unstable periods or time intervals in the data.
This picture shows the obtained calculated monthly prices elasticities, the red dots.
The two black horizontal lines are the boundary boundaries of the region of price elasticities.
Between minus five and five.
And what a similar picture arose for the monthly price elasticity, slopes very similar.
From these, from these two pictures we can conclude that the responsiveness of the imported oil quantity to a change in its price stabilized with tears.
It stabilized after the creation of the.
Um?
Petroleum reserve and no other unstable periods could be detected here.
So let us conclude all the findings based on just one simple analysis.
One simple data set.
A data mining approach for demand and supply data was introduced.
With the aim or we did regression analysis to search for interesting patterns and dependencies.
And found it.
And found an 11 year period of highly unstable US oil imports data.
This is the creation of the US Petroleum Reserve.
Or so local peaks of purchase quantity resulted in linear price elasticity models.
Atypical for demand.
And the second step was worth the monthly price elasticities and the monthly price elasticity slopes to detect stable time intervals.
Where we found that this press elasticities stabilized after the stabilized after the creation of the Petroleum Reserve and no other unstable.
Um was detected.
So this was just a first attempt to use such price elasticity functions, but of course.
A more thorough analysis or consideration of these these methods on other data has to be performed.
Thank you.
